Graphical abstract Hydrogenation of CO2 to methane is a feasible solution to the growing global environmental and energy challenges. Nickel-based catalysts are efficient and cost effective for CO2 methanation. Hernin, we synthesized Mn-promoted Ni/Al2O3 catalysts with facilitated CO2 methanation and elucidated the crucial role of Mn. After Mn doping, NiMn/Al2O3 catalysts showed improved NiO dispersion. Subsequently, H2 reduction and CO2 methanation treatments resulted in reduction of NiO and MnO2 into Ni and MnO, and incorporation of Ni2+ into MnO lattice, forming NiMnOx and creating numerous Ni-NiMnOx interfaces. The abundant oxygen vacancies from NiMnOx could enhance CO2 activation. Moreover, oxygen vacancies at the interface also promote electron transfer from Ni and MnO, leading to electron-poor Ni nanoparticles and thus significantly promoting the *CO methanation. Ultimately, the electron-poor Ni nanoparticles and abundant oxygen vacancies at the Ni-NiMnOx interface jointly facilitate CO2 methanation. Keywords CO2 methanation NiMn/Al2O3 catalysts Ni-NiMnOx interface Electron-poor Ni nanoparticles Oxygen vacancy Enhanced CO2 activation and *CO methanation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Over the past centuries, rising CO2 emission from fossil fuel combustion has disrupted atmospheric CO2 balance and caused severe global environmental concerns, necessitating urgent measures to mitigate its concentration [1–3]. Hydrogenation of CO2 to high-valued chemicals offers a promising approach to reduce atmospheric CO2 level while utilizing green hydrogen derived from renewable energy [4–6]. Among which, catalytic conversion of CO2 and H2 into CH4, known as CO2 methanation or Sabatier reaction, has become a prominent research focus, due to the significance of methane as energy source and raw material for higher hydrocarbons [7,8]. Meanwhile, methane can be easily transported and distributed through existing natural gas infrastructure [9,10]. Nickel-based catalysts are regarded promising for CO2 methanation due to their high activity and low cost [11,12]. However, supported Ni catalysts face inevitable challenges, especially poor low-temperature activity [13,14]. Strategies of promoter introduction have been extensively studied, with manganese (Mn) modification receiving growing interests. For instance, Wu et al. reported the crucial role of Mn in improved dispersion of NiO nanoparticles and generation of more moderate alkaline sites, with the resulting NiMn/Al2O3-ZrO2 catalysts exhibiting outstanding low-temperature CO2 methanation activity and stability [15]. Similarly, Vrijburg and co-workers proposed that MnO clusters could significantly enhance the adsorption and activation of CO2, which commonly limited the application of supported Ni catalysts in low-temperature CO2 hydrogenation [16,17]. On the other hand, in situ temperature-programmed diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (TP-DRIFTS) reflects the “quasi-static” behavior of surface intermediates, but cannot definitively link detected species to the dominant reaction pathway. To address this limitation, advanced infrared technologies, including steady-state isotopic transient kinetic analysis (SSITKA) and modulation excitation spectroscopy (MES), have emerged as powerful tools. By tracking the temporal evolution of intermediates, these methods enable unambiguous identification of active species and mechanistic pathways through their unique ability to correlate the sequence of intermediates formation and consumption [18–22]. Therefore, a comprehensive investigation into the mechanisms by which Mn-modified Ni-based catalysts enhance CO2 methanation is crucial to establish a clear and accurate structure–activity relationship. Herein, we systematically elucidate the crucial role of Mn modification in facilitating CO2 methanation over Ni/Al2O3 catalysts. The obtained NiMn/Al2O3 catalysts demonstrated exceptional activity and stability in CO2 methanation. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM), in situ X-ray diffraction (XRD), H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), in situ Raman, and quasi in situ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) revealed the formation of Ni-NiMnOx interfaces with electron-poor Ni nanoparticles and abundant oxygen vacancies. In situ DRIFTS, kinetic studies and CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) demonstrated enhanced CO2 activation and CO methanation. Accordingly, we established the structure–activity relationship of NiMn/Al2O3 catalysts in CO2 methanation and expounded the vital role of Mn. This work offers new insights for studies on CO2 hydrogenation over promoter-modified heterogeneous catalysts. 2 Experimental details 2.1 Catalyst Preparation Supported NiMn/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared using a deposition–precipitation method. Typically, Al2O3 support (AEROXIDE Alu130, Evonik, 99.6 %) was suspended in 150 mL deionized water, followed by the addition of a certain amount of nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, General Reagent, AR) and manganese nitrate solution (Mn(NO3)2, Aladdin, 50 wt%). Ammonium carbonate solution ((NH4)2CO3, Aladdin, AR, 0.5 M) was then added dropwise under continuous stirring as a precipitant. The mixture was stirred for an additional 30 min, followed by centrifugation and thorough washing with deionized water multiple times. The resulting solid precursor was dried at 60 °C overnight and calcined at 450 °C for 3 h with a heating ramp of 2 °C·min−1. The NiO loading was fixed at 20 wt%, with the MnO2 loading varying from 0 to 20 wt%. For comparison, MnO2/Al2O3 catalyst with 20 wt% MnO2 loading was prepared following a same procedure. The supported NiMn/Al2O3 catalysts were denoted as 20NimMn, where m represented Mn loading (m = 0, 5, 10, 15, and 20 wt%). 2.2 Catalyst characterizations The dispersion of Ni was determined by N2O reactive frontal chromatography (N2O-RFC) using the VDSORB-91i chemisorption instrument. Before test, the samples (75 mg) were dehydrated at 150 °C in Ar for 15 min. Then, the fresh catalysts were heated up to 500 °C in 10 %H2/N2 at a rate of 10 °C·min−1. The corresponding hydrogen consumption was denoted as A1. The reduced samples were then cooled to 75 °C in Ar and the atmosphere was switched to N2O for 60 min to oxidize surface Ni atoms. Afterward, the samples were flushed by Ar for 30 min. Then, the atmosphere was switched back to 10%H2/N2 and the temperature was ramped to 600 °C at 10 °C·min−1. The corresponding hydrogen consumption was denoted as A2. Next, the Ni dispersion (DNi) was calculated according to the equation D Ni = A 2 A 1 × 100 % . High-resolution TEM (HR-TEM) was conducted using a Talos F200S at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. Samples were suspended in ethanol, and 2–3 drops of the slurry were deposited on a copper grid and dried with an infrared lamp. The transport of reduced and reacted samples were conducted under Ar atmosphere (Air Liquid) to prevent their potential oxidation in air. In situ XRD was carried out on a Bruker D8-Advance X-ray powder diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm) at 40 kV and 40 mA. Full scans from 10 to 80° were performed with a scan rate of 10°/min. Additionally, the diffraction peaks of MnO at 30–50° was scanned with a slow rate of 1°/min to obtain better peak resolution. Samples were loaded into an in situ cell (RC-XRD-T01, Jiaxing Puxiang Tech.) and reduced at 500 °C in 60 %H2/N2 (Air Liquid) for 2 h. The sample was then cooled to a certain temperature, followed by the introduction of 15%CO2/60%H2/25%N2 (Air Liquid) or 20%CO/60%H2/20%N2 (Air Liquid) for 1 h. H2-TPR was performed with a homemade chemisorption instrument equipped with an online TCD. Samples were dehydrated at 150 °C in N2 (Air Liquide) for 10 min. After cooling to room temperature in N2, the atmosphere was switched to 10%H2/Ar (Air Liquide) and maintained for 30 min. Afterward, the temperature was ramped to 750 °C at 5 °C·min−1. CO2-TPD was conducted on the same instrument. Samples were first reduced at 500 °C in 60%H2/N2 for 2 h. Afterward, the samples were flushed with Ar for 30 min. After cooling to room temperature in N2, CO2 was introduced for 30 min. Finally, the sample was flushed in Ar for 20 min and then heated to 750 °C at 5 °C·min−1 with N2 as carrier gas. In situ Raman was performed with a Horiba LabRam-HR spectrometer equipped with visible laser excitation at 532 nm generated by a He-Cd laser. The laser was focused on the sample with a confocal microscope equipped with a 350 long-working-distance objective (Olympus BX-30-LWD). The scattered photons were directed and focused onto a single-stage monochromator measured with an ultraviolet-sensitive liquid-N2-cooled CCD (charge-coupled device) detector (Horiba CCD-3000 V). The sample was loaded into an in situ cell and reduced at 500 °C in 60%H2/N2 for 2 h. The sample was then cooled to 250 °C, followed by the introduction of 15%CO2/60%H2/25%N2 for 1 h. Quasi in situ XPS were conducted using a Thermo Fisher ESCALAB250Xi spectrometer with a monochromatic Al Ka X-ray source (1486.68 eV). Before reduction, fresh samples were vacuumed and transferred to the analytical chamber. A pretreatment chamber was used to further activate the samples. The samples were reduced at 500 °C in 60%H2/N2 for 2 h, and subsequently vacuumed and transferred to the analytical chamber. Afterward, the samples were further reacted at 300 °C for 1 h in 15%CO2/60%H2/25%N2 or 20%CO/60%H2/20%N2, which is then vacuumed and transferred to the analytical chamber. Charge calibration was performed by setting the C 1s peak to 284.8 eV. In situ DRIFTS studies were conducted on an FT-IR spectrometer (PerkinElmer Frontier) equipped with an in situ diffuse reflection cell (DR-A01, Jiaxing Puxiang Tech. Ltd.). For in situ TP-DRIFTS, the samples were loaded into the in situ cell and reduced in 60 %H2/N2 at 500 °C for 2h. Afterward, the samples were flushed in Ar for 20 min and cooled to room temperature, with Ar background spectra recorded continuously. Then, 15%CO2/60%H2/25%N2 or 20%CO/60%H2/20%N2, and the samples were heated to specific temperatures at a rate of 10 °C·min−1. In situ MES DRIFTS experiments was conducted as follows: exposure of the reduced sample to a 15 %CO2/85 %N2 mixture for 90 s. Subsequently, a 60%H2/40%N2 atmosphere was switched for another 90 s. This alternating sequence was repeated for 15–20 cycles configuring with 2 scans per spectrum at a resolution of 4 cm−1. The acquire time-domain spectra were mathematically processed by using PSD, according to equation [23]: A k φ k PSD = 2 T ∫ 0 T A ( t ) sin k ω t + φ k PSD d t where T is the length of one cycle, ω is the demodulation frequency, k is the demodulation index (k = 1 in this study), φ is the demodulation phase angle for kω demodulation, and A(t) and Ak are the active surface species response in time- and phase-domain, respectively. Notably, reduced 20Ni appears black and reduced 20Ni15Mn is brown. This difference results in remarkedly stronger infrared signals for reduced 20Ni15Mn reduced compared to 20Ni. For in situ CO2-DRIFTS experiments, after H2 reduction, CO2/N2 (Air Liquide) was introduced at room temperature for 30 min, instead of reactant gas. Afterward, the samples were flushed in Ar for 20 min and then heated to specific temperatures at a rate of 10 °C·min−1 in steps of 25 °C. The thermogravimetry (TG) analysis was performed over a Mettler TGA2 analyzer. About 3–10 mg of the sample was loaded in a crucible and heated from room temperature to 1000 °C in air, with a ramping rate of 10 °C·min−1. 2.3 Activity tests CO2 hydrogenation and CO hydrogenation activities were evaluated in a fixed-bed plug flow reactor, and the gaseous products were analyzed by online gas chromatography (GC2060, Ruimin) equipped with TDX-01 column, FID, TCD, and methane converter. Typically, 50 mg of fresh catalyst was added into a U-shaped quartz tube and fixed with quartz wool. The catalysts were reduced in 60%H2/N2 (total flow rate: 25 mL·min−1) at 500 °C for 2 h. Then, catalytic performance was evaluated from 250 to 450 °C in 15%CO2/60%H2/25%N2 or 20%CO/60%H2/20%N2 in steps of 25/50 °C. Intrinsic activities of 20NimMn were evaluated in the same reactor (total flow rate: 25 mL·min−1). Before the test, the catalysts were diluted by quartz sand to ensure the CO2 conversion below 10 %, eliminating the potential influence of external diffusion (Table S1). The diluted samples were initially reduced in 60%H2/N2 (total flow rate: 25 mL·min−1) at 500 °C for 2 h. Then, intrinsic activities were determined at 300 °C for 2 h in 15%CO2/60%H2/25%N2. 2.4 Kinetic Measurements Kinetic parameters including activation energies and reaction orders, were determined in the same reactor (total flow rate: 25 mL·min−1). Before the test, the catalysts were diluted by quartz sand to ensure the CO2 conversion below 10 %, eliminating the potential influence of external diffusion. The diluted samples were initially reduced in 60%H2/N2 (total flow rate: 25 mL·min−1) at 500 °C for 2 h. The activation energies were determined within 230–270 °C in 15%CO2/60%H2/25%N2, in steps of 10 °C. The activation energies were calculated using the Arrhenius equation: k = A e - E a RT By taking the natural logarithm, the relationship transforms into lnk = l n A - E a R ∙ 1 T where the slope of the lnk versus 1/T plot corresponds to −Ea/R. Since R is gas constant, the activation energy can be directly derived from the slope. To determine the CO2 order, CO2 partial pressures were varied between 0.15 and 0.6 atm with a constant H2 partial pressure of 0.15 atm. The same procedure was made to determine the H2 order, where PH2 was varied between 0.15 and 0.6 atm with the constant PCO2 of 0.15 atm [12]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance of NiMn/Al2O3 catalysts Following H2 reduction at 500 °C for 2 h, the 20NimMn catalysts were evaluated in CO2 hydrogenation in the temperature range of 250-450 °C, with a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 30 L·h−1·gcat -1. After Mn doping, CO2 conversion remarkedly increased from 48.6 % for 20Ni to 75.4 % for 20Ni15Mn, then slightly decreased to 72.5 % over 20Ni20Mn at 300 °C (Fig. 1 a and Fig. S1a; Table S2). All catalysts demonstrated CH4 selectivity above 97.1 % (Fig. 1b and Fig. S1b). Overall, the CH4 yield of 20Ni15Mn (75.1 %) was significantly higher than 20Ni (47.4 %) at 300 °C (Fig. S2). Notably, the 20Ni15Mn catalyst also achieved CH4 yields comparable to state-of-the-art metal catalysts reported in recent literatures (Fig. 1c and Table S3). Furthermore, the Ni dispersion of 20NimMn catalysts was initially determined by N2O-RFC experiments, Mn doping significantly increased Ni dispersion from 30.4 % for 20Ni to 54.7–63.6 % for 20NimMn (Fig. S3 and Table S4). The turnover frequencies (TOF) of 20NimMn were then calculated at 300 °C, following the apparent activity trend and 20Ni15Mn displaying the highest TOF value of 0.441 h−1 (Fig. 1d). The activation energies of 20Ni and 20Ni15Mn were also calculated at 300 °C, with CO2 conversions limited below 10 %. 20Ni displayed activation energies of 128.9 kJ·mol−1 towards CH4 formation and 135.6 kJ·mol−1 towards CO formation, significantly higher than those of 20Ni15Mn that showed 99.1 kJ·mol−1 towards CH4 formation and 88.2 kJ·mol−1 towards CO formation (Fig. 1e). It emphasizes the significance of Mn in facilitating both CO2 activation (producing CO) and CO2 methanation. 100-hour stability tests were also conducted over 20Ni and 20Ni15Mn at 300 °C with a GHSV of 30 L·h−1·gcat -1, exhibiting constant CO2 conversion of 48.3 % and 81.2 %, CH4 selectivity of 98.1 % and 99.8 %, and CH4 yield of 47.4 % and 81.0 %, respectively (Fig. 1f and Fig. S4). 3.2 Textural properties and morphology of NiMn/Al2O3 catalysts To directly observe the morphological changes after Mn modification, TEM analysis was performed over 20Ni and 20Ni15Mn. The Average NiO particle size of fresh samples was 5.8 nm for 20Ni and 3.5 nm for 20Ni15Mn (Fig. S5a and Fig. S6a; Table S5). Following H2 reduction at 500 °C for 2 h, the average Ni particle size was 6.4 and 3.6 nm for 20Ni and 20Ni15Mn, respectively (Fig. 2 a and Fig. S5b). Mn doping appears to effectively promote Ni dispersion and stabilize Ni nanoparticles from aggregation during thermal treatment. After catalyzing CO2 methanation for 1 h, the average Ni particle size remained constant for 20Ni (6.3 nm) and 20Ni15Mn (3.4 nm) (Fig. 2b and Fig. S5c). Moreover, no obvious aggregation of Ni nanoparticles was detected even after 100-h CO2 methanation, with average Ni particle size of 6.4 nm for 20Ni and 3.7 nm for 20Ni15Mn (Fig. S5d and Fig. S6b). HR-TEM was employed to further investigate the surface morphology of 20Ni and 20Ni15Mn. For 20Ni, HR-TEM images of fresh sample exhibited a lattice fringe of 0.210 nm, corresponding to NiO (200) facet (Fig. S7a). For the H2-reduction catalyst, lattice fringes of 0.210 and 0.206 nm were observed, indicative of NiO (200) and Ni (111) facets, respectively (Fig. S7b). Following CO2 methanation, lattice fringes of 0.210 and 0.206 nm remained on 20Ni (Fig. S7c). After catalyzing 100-h of CO2 methanation, 20Ni showed the coexistence of Ni and NiO nanoparticles (Fig. S7d). For 20Ni15Mn, fresh sample displayed lattice fringes of 0.224 and 0.368 nm, indicative of NiO (111) and MnO2 (111) facets, respectively (Fig. S8) [14,24]. After H2 reduction, lattice fringes of 0.206 and 0.252 nm emerged over 20Ni15Mn, corresponding to Ni (111) and MnO (111) facets, respectively, suggesting the reduction of NiO and MnO2 (Fig. 2c) [16,25,26]. After CO2 methanation, significant structural changes were observed. Lattice fringes of 0.243 nm were observed nearby Ni nanoparticles, referring to the significant contraction of MnO lattice (Fig. 2d). Elemental analysis displayed high dispersion of Ni and Mn species under fresh, reduction and reaction conditions, with the fresh sample excluding potential effect of solid solution (Fig. 2e–f and Fig. S9). Linear-scan analysis on individual nickel nanoparticles was also performed on 20Ni15Mn. For the H2-reduced catalysts, no obvious Mn signal was detected around Ni nanoparticles (Fig. 2g). For the catalysts after CO2 methanation, selected regions displayed overlapping of Ni, Mn and O signals (Fig. 2h). Thus, the lattice contraction of MnO phase following CO2 methanation may be ascribed to the incorporation of Ni species into MnO lattice nearby Ni nanoparticle regions [27]. After catalyzing CO2 methanation for 100 h, lattice fringes of 0.206, 0.243, and 0.252 nm remained over 20Ni15Mn, demonstrating its remarkable structural stability under prolonged reaction condition (Fig. S10). 3.3 Bulk and surface structure of NiMn/Al2O3 catalysts In situ XRD was conducted to analyze the bulk structure of 20NimMn catalysts. For fresh samples, NiO phase was characterized by diffraction peaks at 37.2, 43.3, and 62.9°, and Al2O3 phase was resolved at 37.0, 45.5, 66.8, and 67.3° (Fig. S11). No diffraction peak of Mn species was detected, consistent with EDX spectra that showed high dispersion in Mn signal. According to the Scherrer equation, the crystalline size of NiO followed the order 20Ni (5.2 nm) > 20Ni5Mn (4.2 nm) > 20Ni15Mn (3.4 nm), indicating the promoting role of Mn modification in NiO dispersion, aligned with TEM observations [16]. Following H2 reduction, diffraction peaks at 44.5, 51.8, and 76.4° that assigned to Ni, and 35.2, 40.9, and 59.2° that referred to MnO emerged over 20Ni15Mn, indicating the reduction of NiO and MnO2, respectively (Fig. 3 a). For the catalyst after CO2 methanation, diffraction peaks of MnO shifted from 35.2°/40.9°to 35.5°/41.0° (Fig. 3b). Such a shift of MnO phase to higher angles can be ascribed to the incorporation of Ni2+ into MnO lattice. Compared with Mn2+, the smaller ionic radius of Ni2+ ions would lead to MnO lattice contraction, decrease in interplanar spacing and increase in diffraction angles, following the Bragg’s law [27]. H2-TPR was then conducted to investigate structural properties and reducibility of 20Ni, 20Mn and 20Ni15Mn catalysts. Fresh 20Ni exhibited a reduction peak at 497 °C, attributed to the reduction of NiO into Ni (Fig. 3c, Fig. S12 and Table S6) [28]. Fresh 20Mn showed two reduction peaks at 320 and 418 °C, referring to the sequential reduction of MnO2 to Mn2O3 and MnO, respectively [29]. Upon Mn doping, 20Ni15Mn exhibited three reduction peaks at 288, 377, and 467 °C corresponding to the reduction of MnO2 into Mn2O3, Mn2O3 into MnO, and NiO into Ni, respectively. The lower reduction temperature for NiO nanoparticles over 20Ni15Mn indicates the enhanced reducibility after Mn modification [30,31]. In situ Raman spectra were collected to obtain detailed structural information at the molecular level following H2 reduction and CO2 methanation. The Raman peaks at 634 and 556 cm−1 could be ascribed to symmetric vibrations of Mn-O bond and asymmetric stretching of Mn-O-Mn, respectively (Fig. 3d and Table S7) [32–34]. The increased ratio of Mn-O-Mn bond can be related to the Mn4+ → Mn3+ → Mn2+ process, implying the generation of oxygen vacancies [34]. Thus, the ratio of intensities towards Mn-O-Mn and Mn-O bonds was calculated and followed the order reacted sample (1.02) > reduced sample (0.91) > fresh sample (0.78), indicating the presence of abundant oxygen vacancies at surface regions. Quasi in situ XPS analysis was conducted to characterize the chemical state of surface species over 20Ni and 20Ni15Mn. For fresh samples, Ni2+ species were identified at 855.5 and 873.1 eV for 20Ni, and 855.8 and 873.5 eV for 20Ni15Mn (Fig. 3e and Fig. S13) [35]. For H2-reduced samples, XPS spectra revealed Ni0 species at 852.2 and 869.4 eV for 20Ni, and 852.4 and 869.7 eV for 20Ni15Mn [36]. 20Ni15Mn demonstrated a higher Ni0 ratio (24.3 %) compared to 20Ni (16.8 %), suggesting the superior reducibility of 20Ni15Mn, conforming to H2-TPR profiles (Table S7). Notably, the slight shift of Ni0 species to higher binding energy after Mn modifications could be attributed to the formation of Ni-MnO interface [38]. Following CO2 methanation, Niδ+ species that assigned to NiMnOx, emerged at 854.5 and 872.1 eV over 20Ni15Mn, consistent with HR-TEM and XRD results (Fig. 3e, Figs. S13 and S14) [37]. The Mn 3p and O 1s spectra of 20Ni15Mn were also analyzed. The XPS spectra of Mn 3p for 20Ni15Mn showed the presence of Mn4+, Mn3+, and Mn2+, with binding energy of 643.2–643.4 eV, 641.8–642.1 eV, and 640.4 eV, respectively (Fig. 3f) [17]. The Mn2+ ratio of 20Ni15Mn increased from 0.314 to 0.550 after H2 reduction, and 0.575 following CO2 methanation, indicating the existence of abundant oxygen vacancies, consistent with in situ Raman results (Table S7). The abundance of oxygen vacancies was also evidenced by the O 1 s spectra of 20Ni15Mn. Adsorbed oxygen, oxygen vacancy, and lattice oxygen were identified at 533.1–533.3 eV, 531.2–531.5 eV, and 530.0–530.2 eV, respectively (Fig. S15) [39]. The peak intensity towards oxygen vacancy is notably high and exhibit a slight increase trend after H2 reduction and CO2 methanation, further confirming the abundance of oxygen vacancies on the 20Ni15Mn surface. 3.4 CO2 methanation mechanism of the NiMn/Al2O3 catalysts CO2 methanation mechanism has been extensively studied and can be divided into two primary routes: CO and non-CO route [40,41]. The CO route is characterized by the presence of *CO, while the non-CO route is known for the gradual hydrogenation of *CO2 into CH4, without generating any *CO (Fig. S16). The potential participation of *CO in CO2 methanation was evaluated by GHSV-dependency experiments over 20Ni15Mn at 250 °C. As GHSV increased from 30 to 300 L·h−1·gcat -1, the CH4 selectivity of 20Ni15Mn decreased from 98.9 % to 91.7 %, implying the involvement of *CO in CO2 methanation (Fig. S17) [42,43]. Reaction orders were further calculated over 20Ni and 20Ni15Mn at 300 °C. 20Ni and 20Ni15Mn revealed H2 and CO2 orders of −0.3∼0.1 and 0.5 towards CO production, 0.5–0.6 and −0.2∼0.1 towards CH4 production, respectively (Table S8). The CO2 activation predominantly depends on CO2 partial pressure for 20Ni and 20Ni15Mn, following an associative mechanism [12]. Compared to 20Ni, the slight increased H2 order and decreased CO2 order towards CO production on 20Ni15Mn implies the increased ratio of redox mechanism [44]. Moreover, the significant increase in H2 order towards CH4 production highlights the superior hydrogenation capability of 20Ni15Mn than 20Ni [45]. In situ TP-DRIFTS was then performed to monitor the surface species over 20Ni and 20Ni15Mn during CO2 methanation. After H2 reduction, spectra were collected with the temperature rising from 50 to 400 °C. The spectra showed the presence of monodentate bicarbonate (1440, 1649–1653 cm−1), [22] monodentate carbonate (1380 and 1547 cm−1), [45,46] formate (1591–1593 and 2902–2909 cm−1), [46] linear *CO (2018 cm−1), [47] bridged *CO (1843–1920 cm−1), [48] and CH4 (1304–1305, 3016–3017 cm−1) (Fig. 4 a and Fig. S18a). As the temperature rise, 20Ni displayed the presence of bicarbonate and carbonate since 50 °C, with bicarbonate disappearing at 325 °C (Fig. S18b). Formate appeared at 75 °C and began to decompose since 300 °C, with CH4 generated since 250 °C. For 20Ni15Mn, bicarbonate and carbonate emerged at 50 °C, and depleted until 275 and 400 °C, respectively (Fig. 4b). Formate appeared at 100 °C, increased until 300 °C, and disappeared at 350 °C, accompanied by gradual increase in *CO and CH4 since 225 and 235 °C, respectively. The appearance and evolution of intermediates over 20Ni and 20Ni15Mn suggests an associative mechanism, consistent with kinetic studies. Subsequently, in situ time-resolved DRIFTS under alternating CO2/H2 atmospheres was conducted at 350 °C to elucidate the active surface species and primary reaction pathways for CO2 methanation [20]. Upon introducing CO2, both 20Ni and 20Ni15Mn catalysts exhibited immediate formation of monodentate bicarbonate, monodentate carbonate and formate, indicating CO2 adsorption and activation (Fig. 4c and S19a). Notably, *CO displayed a delayed response over 20Ni15Mn. After switching to H2, the sudden generation and gradual consumption of surface intermediates, including monodentate bicarbonate, monodentate carbonate, and formate was observed over 20Ni, while 20Ni15Mn exhibited the rapid formation and depletion of monodentate bicarbonate, monodentate carbonate, formate, and *CO (Fig. 4d and S19b). To identify key intermediates and their dynamic roles in CO2 methanation, phase-resolved spectra were obtained to reveal the time-relayed responses of surface species [49]. For 20Ni, monodentate bicarbonate and formate displayed a phase angle of φ = 280°, with the absence of carbonate suggesting its role as spectator (Fig. S19c). 20Ni15Mn resolved monodentate bicarbonate, monodentate carbonate, and formate at φ = 270°, with *CO species at φ = 290° (delayed by 20°, relative to formate dissociation) (Fig. 4e). These results suggest that the activation of CO2 undergoes an associative pathway and the phase delay of 10° between 20Ni (280°) and 20Ni15Mn (270°) indicate the superior CO2 activation on 20Ni15Mn. The above results indicate a dominant formate mechanism on 20Ni, while 20Ni15Mn follows an associative mechanism, likely due to Mn-promoted formate generation and dissociation. Additionally, monodentate carbonate appears to be a spectator on 20Ni. The CO2 adsorption ability of H2-reduced catalysts was further investigated under inert atmosphere by in situ TP-DRIFTS following CO2 adsorption. Both 20Ni and 20Ni15Mn exhibited monodentate bicarbonate and carbonate since 30 °C, with 20Ni15Mn demonstrating higher desorption temperature (Fig. S20). Moreover, additional bidentate bicarbonate was observed at 1627 cm−1 over 20Ni15Mn [50]. These findings confirm the superior CO2 activation ability of 20Ni15Mn, which was also supported by CO2-TPD profiles. As shown in Fig. S21, 20Ni15Mn showed a stronger CO2 desorption peak compared to 20Ni. The enhanced CO2 adsorption is consistent with in situ TP-DRIFTS during CO2 methanation. 3.5 Structure-activity relationship of NiMn/Al2O3 catalysts TEM images and in situ XRD patterns of fresh samples revealed the promoting role of Mn in NiO dispersion, resulting in smaller NiO nanoparticles over 20Ni15Mn. Following H2 reduction, NiO and MnO2 was reduced into Ni and MnO, with 20Ni15Mn showcasing superior NiO reducibility. Moreover, the newly formed Ni-MnO interface facilitates electron transfer from Ni to MnO, driven by the electron receptor nature of oxygen vacancies [38,51,52]. This results in electron-poor Ni nanoparticles, as confirmed by quasi in situ XPS. After CO2 methanation, HRTEM observations confirm the formation of NiMnOx species adjacent to Ni nanoparticles. This phenomenon appears to originate from the interaction between unreduced NiO and MnO, as supported by in situ XRD. Crucially, since the spatial proximity of unreduced NiO to metallic Ni NPs, the newly emerged NiMnOx species preferentially localize near metallic Ni NPs, thereby generating numerous Ni-NiMnOx interfaces. On the other hand, in situ Raman and quasi in situ XPS jointly suggest the abundance of oxygen vacancies on catalysts surface, likely originating from MnO and NiMnOx species. Furthermore, in situ Raman showed that the reacted 20Ni15Mn with Ni-NiMnOx interface exhibits more oxygen vacancies than the reduced one, suggesting a higher oxygen vacancies density at the Ni-NiMnOx interface than the Ni-MnO interface. The increase in oxygen vacancies can be attributed to the incorporation of Ni2+ into the MnO lattice, which introduces lattice defects, lowers the formation energy of oxygen vacancies, and ultimately generates Niδ+ species, as evidenced by quasi in situ XPS. These oxygen vacancies could also enhance the CO2 activation, as supported by kinetic studies, in situ DRIFTS, and CO2-TPD profiles. In situ TP-DRIFTS of 20Ni15Mn exhibited the presence of *CO, suggesting the potential enhancement of Mn doping in CO methanation. Thus, 20NimMn catalysts were evaluated in CO hydrogenation at 250 °C with a GHSV of 30 L·h−1·gcat -1. Surprisingly, 20Ni15Mn showed outstanding activity, with CO conversion of 100.0 %, CH4 selectivity of 90.1 %, and CH4 yield of 90.1 %, approximately 12.3 times higher than 20Ni in CH4 yield (7.1 %) (Fig. 5 a–b and Fig. S22; Table S9). Mn doping also improved long-term stability of 20Ni15Mn by inhibiting carbon deposition, as proven in TG analysis (Fig. S23 and Fig. S24) [53,54]. According to the literature, metallic Ni is regarded as crucial active site for CO hydrogenation, implying the importance of Ni0 species for the exceptional CO methanation activity of 20Ni15Mn [55,56]. As confirmed by structural characterizations, CO and CO2 methanation treatments led to similar structural changes on 20Ni15Mn (Fig. 5c–e, Figs. S25 and S26). Quasi in situ XPS suggests that oxygen vacancies at the Ni-MnO interface appears to facilitate electron transfer from Ni to MnO, resulting in electron-poor nature for Ni nanoparticles, as confirmed by the shift of Ni0 species to higher binding energy after Mn doping (Fig. 5e). Electron-poor Ni nanoparticles were beneficial to the CO adsorption and activation, as evidenced by in situ TP-DRIFTS during CO hydrogenation (Fig. 5f and Fig. S27) [57–59]. Furthermore, these electron-poor nanoparticles at the Ni-NiMnOx interface could remarkedly facilitate *CO methanation over 20Ni15Mn during CO2 methanation. 4 Conclusions In summary, we prepared a series of Mn-modified Ni/Al2O3 catalysts and clarified the enhancement of Mn doping in CO2 methanation. The addition of Mn notably improved the Ni dispersion over 20Ni15Mn, resulting in smaller Ni nanoparticles. H2 reduction treatments and CO2 methanation reaction led to the reduction of NiO and MnO2, and incorporation of Ni2+ into MnO lattice, resulting in the formation of NiMnOx phase and generating numerous Ni-NiMnOx interfaces. NiMnOx species possesses abundant oxygen vacancies that benefit the CO2 activation, especially formate formation and dissociation. Subsequently, oxygen vacancies at the Ni-MnO interface entails charge interaction, resulting in electron-poor Ni nanoparticles, which promotes the *CO methanation. Therefore, our work systemically elaborated the crucial role of Mn modification in CO2 methanation, where electron-poor Ni nanoparticles and oxygen vacancies at the Ni-NiMnOx interface remarkedly promote the CO2 activation and CO methanation processes, respectively, ultimately facilitating the CO2 methanation reaction. coredata.dc:description: Hydrogenation of CO2 to methane is a feasible solution to the growing global environmental and energy challenges. Nickel-based catalysts are efficient and cost effective for CO2 methanation. Hernin, we synthesized Mn-promoted Ni/Al2O3 catalysts with facilitated CO2 methanation and elucidated the crucial role of Mn. After Mn doping, NiMn/Al2O3 catalysts showed improved NiO dispersion. Subsequently, H2 reduction and CO2 methanation treatments resulted in reduction of NiO and MnO2 into Ni and MnO, and incorporation of Ni2+ into MnO lattice, forming NiMnOx and creating numerous Ni-NiMnOx interfaces. The abundant oxygen vacancies from NiMnOx could enhance CO2 activation. Moreover, oxygen vacancies at the interface also promote electron transfer from Ni and MnO, leading to electron-poor Ni nanoparticles and thus significantly promoting the *CO methanation. Ultimately, the electron-poor Ni nanoparticles and abundant oxygen vacancies at the Ni-NiMnOx interface jointly facilitate CO2 methanation.

coredata.dc:title: Manganese-promoted Ni/Al2O3 catalysts for effective CO2 methanation
